required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on December 16, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Probiotics for Inflammation in Pediatric Chronic Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Probiotics for Inflammation in Pediatric Chronic Pain

brief_summary.textblock: To examine benefits of a probiotic for youth with chronic pain and obesity.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the current study: (1) examine whether an 8-week supplement of a single-strain probiotic (Lactobascillus Plantarum, Lp299v) reduces systemic inflammation; (2) determine whether reductions in systemic inflammation will correlate with reductions in pain, disability, mood impairment and changes in mechanical pain threshold and mechanical pain sensitization; (3) Explore whether reductions in systemic inflammation will correlate with reductions in other outcomes.

primary_outcome.description: Change in circulating C-Reactive Protein after 8 weeks of probiotic supplement.

secondary_outcome.description: Change in worst pain intensity (based on a 0-10 numeric rating scale) over the past 2 weeks after 8 weeks of probiotic supplement.

arm_group.description: Participants will be given the probiotic supplement Lp299v. The supplement is taken by mouth in the form of capsules. Participants will undergo a screening visit. After 8 weeks of taking Lp299v, they will return for their final visit. Blood will be drawn before and after the 8-week intervention.

intervention.description: Dietary Supplement: Lp299v. Lp299v is a commercially available probiotic supplement manufactured and distributed by Next Foods.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Male or female biological sex
2. 13-17 years of age
3. Body Mass Index â‰¥95th percentile for sex and age
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Probiotic (or prebiotic) supplement use or antibiotic use within the past month
2. Chronic inflammatory or autoimmune disease with the exception of well-controlled hypothyroidism or intermittent or mild persistent asthma not requiring the use of daily inhaled steroids
3. Chronic pain conditions other than headache or migraine
4. Patients who have had a poor response to blood draw or immunizations in the past
5. Chronic use of medications known to alter gastrointestinal function or inflammation (e.g. metformin, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications)
6. Any condition that, in the investigator's opinion, may compromise study participation or may confound the interpretation of the study results
7. Use of illicit drugs
8. Females who are pregnant or lactating
